some called out to their parents and brothers, some called out to their husbands and masters, and so they wailed and cried in various ways;

World-Honored One!

Because his parents, siblings, wife, relatives, and friends are bound by affection and love, they are confused and disordered like this.
May the World-Honored One, for the sake of delivering all, go there.

they wanted to sigh deeply, but out of respect for the Buddha, they did not dare to breathe out, and remained there with their throats constricted.
At that time, the Buddha said to the parents, brothers, relatives, and acquaintances of the elder:
Why do you weep sorrowfully and be deluded by this illusory dharma?
Those people spoke to the Buddha at the same time, saying:
World-Honored One!
In this city, only this person is intelligent, wise, upright, and extremely handsome. He is in the prime of his youth and is unsurpassed among all people.
We think of him constantly, never leaving our minds. The people all look up to him and never tire of gazing at him.
His speech is gentle, and he is filial to his parents and respectful to his brothers;
Moreover, he has abundant wealth, gold, silver, lapis lazuli, agate, coral, amber, and his storehouses are overflowing with precious treasures;
He also has carriages, horses, food and drink, medicine, clothing, bedding, male and female servants.
In this way, he had everything, but one day he died. Therefore, we grieve and mourn for him, unable to control ourselves.
Excellent!
World-Honored One!
We only wish that you would skillfully expound the Dharma for us, enabling us to be free from all afflictions and never again experience such suffering from now on;
They will be able to cut off the fundamental afflictions of greed, anger, and delusion;
They will be able to cross over the shore of birth, old age, sickness, and death;
They will forever leave behind the ocean of worry, sorrow, suffering, and distress;
Wherever they are born, they will encounter the buddhas and meet with good spiritual friends, and will not encounter evil conditions.
At that time the World-Honored One said to the elder's parents, relatives, acquaintances, and the great assembly:
Have you ever seen anyone who is born but does not age, does not get sick, and does not die?
These people said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
We have never seen such a thing.
The Buddha further said to the great assembly:
If you wish to be free from birth, old age, sickness, death, worry, sorrow, suffering, and distress, do not think of the bonds of affection and love;
Set your mind on the right view and take refuge in the Three Treasures.
Why is this?
In the world, there is none who surpasses the Buddha in guiding the blind, the ignorant, and the foolish.
Among the leaders of merchants and the kings of physicians, there is none who is equal to the Buddha in terms of the marks of excellence.
Why is this so?
The body of the TathÄgata is the king of medicines, and the Dharma taught by the Buddha is the excellent medicine.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
In the worlds of the ten directions, there is none who is born but will die.
The path of birth and death comes and goes, and only the Dharma can eliminate it.
There is no one in the lands of the ten directions who can save those whose lives have ended.
Only the Buddha can eliminate and cut off [suffering], therefore I take refuge in the Buddha.
The Buddha further told the great assembly:
How do you know what is called death?
The people replied:
We do not know.
World-Honored One!
The Buddha told the great assembly:
Killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, idle chatter, envy, and hatred and delusion - if a person engages in these ten unwholesome deeds, they are called dead.

Their speech is coarse and evil, and they often harm others;
They are mad, foolish, and lazy, with unsettled minds;

Unable to uphold pure precepts, lazy and not diligent,
Such people are all called dead.
Those who are fond of committing evil deeds, will be reborn in the evil destinies;
If a person practices good deeds, then they will be reborn in the heavens.
If a person has no faith in the Buddha, and also does not practice the Dharma,
Those who practice non-dharma, are then called dead.
He further addressed the great assembly, saying:

If a person attains wealth and nobility but has no arrogant mind, their mind is always at ease, they do not exalt themselves or look down on others, they treat everyone equally, regarding them as themselves, although they attain wealth and nobility, their mind is no different, they always contemplate impermanence, not considering it their own, seeing it as a poisonous enemy, and understand that all phenomena will eventually separate.
Having understood this, they diligently cultivate;
knowing that all phenomena have nothing to rely on, they do not consider fame and gain as their own, and are also not attached to any dust;
they always cultivate their mind and befriend the wise;
they do not associate with bad friends, always seeking to be far away;
they never go against the Dharma taught by the Buddha.

are called dead.
He further addressed the assembly:
Do you know that there is birth, old age, sickness, and death, and that the spirit transmigrates in this world and the next, taking on a new form?
The people replied:
We do not know, World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
You should know!
Sentient beings are bound by these four things, their spirits transmigrate through the five paths, not knowing where they come from in life and where they go in death.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The impermanent is considered permanent, the impure is considered pure,
Speaking of real suffering as happiness, and taking what is not-self to be a self.

If there are people who can understand the true great Dharma,

If a person sees the turbidity and cuts off the basis of the three poisons,
They will surely be able to accomplish the unsurpassed great Dharma.
He further addressed the great assembly:ğŸ”½Because of afflictions, various causes and conditions arise;

For this reason, one revolves in the cycle of birth and death.
Form does not reach the next world, and feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness do not reach the next world.
Why is it so?
Because the five aggregates cannot be obtained, are not solid, and do not remain for a moment.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Because of the various bonds and afflictions, one gives rise to various evil causes and conditions,
And because of these causes and conditions, one experiences immeasurable suffering.
Because of experiencing various sufferings, one further gives rise to immeasurable bonds,

The beautiful colors of the world are like bubbles on water,
All the various sufferings are likened to rain bubbles,

He further addressed the great assembly:
Earth does not go to the next world, nor do water, fire, or wind.
Why is it so?

Because earth is without awareness and knowledge, the four elements are without consciousness, and earth is itself false and composed of the four elements. For this reason, it does not go to the next world.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Among all dharmas, there is no form and no color,
Also, there is nothing to be aware of, false and without reality.
The four elements are provisionally combined, soft and weak, without firmness,
Wishing to make it reach the next world, in the end there is no such place.
He further told the great assembly:
The eye does not go to the next world, nor do the ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind.
Why is it so?
Because the eye is empty, without self, impermanent, and does not remain for a moment.

Even if you want to stop it, it cannot be done. When there are conditions, it arises; when conditions disperse, it ceases. When arising, it does not come from anywhere; when ceasing, it does not go anywhere.
The ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind are also like this.
All people should know!
These six sense faculties exist when conditions come together, and do not exist when conditions disperse.
It is like a guest who cannot stay long.

It is also like a debtor who calculates the days to repay the debt. When the days are finished, he leaves, and there is never a time of staying. When he leaves, it becomes empty, and in the end, he cannot be found. There is no coming and going.
The six sense faculties are also like this.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The sense faculties are not solid; this dharma is like empty space.
It is not stable and has no life; it cannot be grasped as 'mine.'
Because of conditions, there is function; in the end, there is no certainty.
The dharma formed by combination changes in the world and cannot be obtained.

You should contemplate impermanence and not be apart from this thought.

In my past innumerable lives, I was various kings, and with my head, eyes, marrow, brain, hands, feet, country, city, wife, children, elephants, horses, seven treasures, palaces, towers, and the implements of the five pleasures, I gave them all in charity.
At that time, I also cultivated pure precepts without any transgression. If someone came to ask for these things, I would joyfully give them without any angry thoughts or jealous intentions;

He further addressed the great assembly:
You should observe that impermanence will never abandon anyone.
The TathÄgata has attained omniscience, his physical body has excellent characteristics, and he has accomplished everything, yet he cannot escape it.
The buddhas of the past, present, and future also return to impermanence.
Therefore, you should deeply contemplate the law of impermanence!

If you can do so, you will no longer have a mind of affection and attachment, nor will you have thoughts of greed, anger, or ignorance. You will permanently end the suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death, and will be free from all unwholesome dharmas. You will increase immeasurable pure practices and deeply understand the twelve links of dependent origination.
For these causes and conditions, you will always encounter the buddhas.
Why is it so?
If a person can understand the twelve links of dependent origination, it is the same as seeing the Dharma;
If one sees the Dharma, it is called seeing the Buddha;
Those who wish to see the Buddha should uphold pure precepts and have impeccable conduct.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:

The future buddhas firmly establish sentient beings, and the present buddhas,
In buddha-lands as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, these buddhas also return to impermanence.
The power of impermanence does not abandon the desire realm, the form realm, or the formless realm,
The sages, kings, nobles, low, and high, it also does not abandon,
The buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, and those in training and no longer training.
It does not select wealth or beauty, does not ask about strength or weakness, or about great wisdom,
It firmly grasps people.
Therefore, you should know that impermanence is the greatest suffering, and you should seek the true Dharma.
Gardens, ponds, flowers, and fruits in abundance, the country, city, wife, and children,
Head and eyes given in charity, with these merits, seeking the Buddha's path.
In the past, I gave away my hands and feet. With such deeds,
Cultivating patience, when a hawk chased a dove, I cut off my flesh to ransom it,
For the unsurpassed path, enduring all suffering and pain.
Long practicing the difficult path, I defeated Mara, under the tree of enlightenment,
Attaining the path of Buddhahood, free from all defilements, I turned the Dharma wheel,
In the Deer Park.
I have already subdued the angry yakshas, dwelling in the seven mountains, in the Himalayas.

Transforming them into disciples, and their retinues, I have all subdued them,
But I cannot subdue the great power of impermanence.
I, among the logicians and non-Buddhists,
With the true Dharma to discuss together, all are not as good as me.
The sentient beings of different destinies, transforming them to be disciples,
But I cannot subdue the great power of impermanence.
The bonds of self-view, craving, hatred, and delusion,
Such deluded and dark dharmas, all have already been eliminated,
Yet the great lamp of wisdom illuminates the trichiliocosm,
Yet they cannot subdue the great power of impermanence.
Subduing the demon king of the heavens and his troops,
Destroying the great blindness and illuminating with the light of the true Dharma.
Also subduing the various masters of debate and astrologers,
Yet they cannot subdue the great power of impermanence.
